ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ACCIDENTS INVOLVING SBS BUSES
(Measures to prevent)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Communications what measures are being taken to prevent or alleviate the increasing number of accidents involving buses, which have been hazardous to commuters and pedestrians.
ACCIDENTS INVOLVING SBS BUSES
(Reasons)


    2. Mr R. Sinnakaruppan asked the Minister for Communications what are the reasons for the spate of accidents involving SBS buses in the last few months and what action has been taken to remedy the situation.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to take the first two Questions together as they are related?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, in the first two months of this year, there were nine major traffic accidents involving SBS buses that attracted widespread public attention and concern. The Traffic Police has completed its investigations of these accidents. The investigations revealed that the accidents were due to human error and not to mechanical defects.

    Although the nine accidents received considerable media publicity, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Traffic Police records indicate that they do not represent a worsening trend. The accident rate for SBS buses for the first two months of this year is 0.96 accidents per 100,000 km. This is about the same as the accident rate for last year. In comparison with other large urban public transport operators world-wide, for example, Hong Kong (1.8 accidents per 100,000 km), Paris (9.7 accidents per 100,000 km) and UK (0.34 accidents per 100,000 km), SBS' safety record is relatively good.

    Nevertheless, in view of the recent spate of serious accidents, SBS has instituted further measures to enhance its safety record. The new safety programmes that SBS has implemented recently should help to increase safety awareness amongst bus drivers. The LTA will continue to monitor the situation and will ensure that all the necessary corrective and preventive measures are taken to reduce the number of serious accidents.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kampong Glam GRC): I would like to ask the Minister whether he agrees that the drivers are

Column: 837

expected to work long hours, particularly in one of the shifts, eg, starting at about 4.30 am and another shift starting at 5.00 am, and some of these shifts finish at 4.30 pm or even 8.00 pm (12-15 hours). Are the drivers overworked in this respect?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, driver fatigue has been suggested as one of the factors contributing to these accidents. I cannot rule out this possibility and, in fact, because of the tight labour market, SBS has been facing tremendous difficulty in recruiting good bus drivers. Currently, there is a shortage of 300-400 drivers. Because the company has a responsibility to meet basic bus service standards and to improve its level of service, including extending its road network to cover new areas, SBS bus drivers have been asked to take on greater responsibilities and work longer hours, as suggested by the Member.

    As I said, the specific causes of these various accidents have been investigated and the Traffic Police has made its conclusions and will be releasing its results. Whether it is due specifically to driver fatigue is not known. The point is, according to SBS, some of the accidents had happened at the beginning of shifts rather than at the end of shifts, and some of the accidents had happened after a rest day rather than at the end of a long period of rostered work. Therefore, in the case of the nine accidents, there is no correlation between driver fatigue and the accidents. But it is a cause for concern that some of the drivers are working long hours and this is something that the SBS management must look into and I believe it is looking into.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister what is the average number of hours worked by the bus drivers per week and on a daily basis? As the Minister has said, the accidents could be due to human error or fatigue. May I also ask the Minister whether there are plans to limit the number of hours that the drivers have to drive at a stretch before they need to rest and to limit the number of hours of overtime work per day or per week?

Column: 838



     Mr Mah Bow Tan: The average number of hours worked per day is something like 9-9 1/2 hours. This is on a continuous basis but in between there are rest periods. The question is whether the rest periods are sufficient and this is determined by the rosters and schedules that the bus drivers are given. SBS and the unions are having another look at the schedules. Schedules are looked at on a regular basis but in view of these concerns they are re-looking at the schedules again to see whether there is sufficient rest time.

    In so far as whether we will limit the number of hours worked, at the moment there is no reason for us to limit the number of hours worked, including overtime hours, because there is no positive correlation between the number of hours worked and the accidents. As I said, the accident rate has not shown a worsening trend. The number of hours worked and the rosters have not been any different from those in the past. The drivers have been working these hours and they have been working on the rosters that they are currently working today. The implication of this is that SBS should relook at some of these working conditions, including the terms and conditions of service so that it is able to minimise the number of overtime hours of work. To require them to cut down the number of hours worked immediately as a result of this will inevitably mean a curtailment of service because it is not possible for them to be able to recruit this number of drivers. So there has to be a very conscious effort made on the part of the management to make sure that drivers are properly trained and there are sufficient measures in place to ensure that the drivers adhere to traffic rules. Ultimately it is also important for all road users to cooperate with the drivers on the road to make sure there is as low a traffic accident rate as possible on our roads.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask the Minister how many of these drivers who were involved in the recent spate of bus accidents were work permit holders?

Column: 839



     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, I do not have that information available to me.

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: Sir, I am quite happy to note that there is no correlation between worker fatigue and the accidents of late. But what is alarming is that I am given to understand that there are about 33% Malaysians working in Singapore, many of whom stay in Johor Baru. Let us say they work in the morning shift at 4.30 ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Sinnakaruppan, could you ask your question?

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: Yes. I want to ask the Minister, if some of the workers leave their house at 3.00 am or 3.30 am and reach home at 10.00 pm, how much rest can they have? Therefore, in future, this could lead to a lot more problems. As the Minister has just said, because of a shortage of bus drivers, the present workforce is asked to work longer hours. I see that this problem could get worse and it could possibly result in more accidents.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the starting point is that we must determine whether there is a direct positive correlation between the number of hours worked, the fact that they are Malaysian drivers, the fact that their rosters are as long as they are today, and the current nine accidents, before we can make those conclusions. Having said that, it is a fact that there are a lot of drivers who are on work permit at the moment. This is a result of the inability of SBS to recruit more Singaporeans to drive buses. It is not an easy job. The pay and the working conditions must be commensurate and must be attractive enough to draw Singaporeans to work in this kind of job. But, as the Member may be aware, in Singapore today there is a very tight labour market. There are many alternative jobs. There are many alternative jobs even in the transportation sector, whether it is driving taxis or container trucks. Therefore, it is important for SBS to recognise this and to do something about this. But there will always be this need for foreign workers on work permits for quite a long time to come in this particular sector. I am not aware of the exact number but it is close to 20-30%. I do not think it is

Column: 840

as high as 33%. But if SBS wants to recruit more drivers, it would have to do so by making a fundamental review of its terms and conditions of service.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: The Minister has quoted figures to show that Paris and Hong Kong have the worst bus accident records than Singapore. I have two questions. Surely, the important thing is whether or not Paris and Hong Kong have a world-class transport system or have they proclaimed to have one. The second question is: although the Minister says that our figure is quite low (0.96 accidents per 100,000 km), will the Minister say that even such a figure is not acceptable and he will take steps to reduce it, at least to the UK level?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Let me correct the Member for Potong Pasir. First of all, we have not achieved our objective of having a world-class transport system. This is an objective that we have set ourselves. This is an objective that we will have to take many, many years to achieve. At the moment, there are things in our public transport system that are not satisfactory and I have said this many times. But to say that and to link it with the current spate of accidents, I think, is stretching his licence as an Opposition Member a little bit too far.

    Yes, I agree that the accident rate can be further reduced. Every accident that takes place must be a source of anguish and pain for everybody concerned, not just for the victims but it must be so for the drivers, the management and for all of us who are directly or indirectly involved in public transportation. This is not something to be taken lightly. But the point I want to make is that SBS has taken measures. It has viewed these accidents with concern. The authorities have expressed their concern in no uncertain terms. We have asked them to take steps to further improve the situation. Can the accident rate be reduced further? I believe it can, in the same way that the public transport operators in Singapore have reduced their accident rates over the years. Surely, they can reduce it further and I strongly believe, if they take the steps that they are taking, that it will be

Column: 841

reduced further. So it is incumbent upon all of us who are involved to reduce the accident rate to as low as is humanly possible. I cited those figures to show that in comparison with other urban public transport operators, our public transport operators are not doing too badly. They are not the worst; they are not the best either. Therefore, there is always room for improvement.

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: I would like to ask the Minister, given the fact that very few Singaporeans take up the job as bus drivers, and the fact that the Chairman of SBS has announced that bus drivers get about 20% less than other transport operators, taxis and so on, would SBS consider increasing the remuneration for bus drivers?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, this is something for the SBS management and unions to consider together with all the other necessary measures that would have to be taken in order to minimise the rate of accidents.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, may I ask the Minister, since there may be some difficulty in getting local workers, whether there is a limit in the percentage of foreign workers that can be employed as bus drivers, and if this percentage is too small, whether he should ask the Labour Minister to increase the number, so that we can have more bus drivers to cater for the industry.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, there is a limit at the moment to the number of foreign workers that can be employed by SBS as bus drivers, in the same way as there are limits or quotas to the number of work permit holders in other industries. I think this is something that we would have to proceed very cautiously if we were to lift the limit or remove the cap.

    Public transport or bus services is an essential industry. It is something that we want to make sure continues to have as many Singaporeans as possible. Recognising that it is not possible to have a 100% Singaporean workforce, the

Column: 842

Labour Ministry has allowed SBS to employ foreign workers. It is sufficient at the moment because I believe the quota for foreign workers, as far as SBS is concerned, has not been reached yet. So I do not think there is a necessity to lift the quota. I do not think the question arises at this stage. But the important thing is to make sure that the terms and conditions of service are sufficiently attractive for as many bus drivers as possible as are needed in order to provide the kind of service that Singaporeans expect of them.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: To allay the fears of bus commuters in Singapore, will the Government take immediate measures to try and cut down this rate of accidents caused by SBS buses? With a view to improving the situation, will the Government ask the bus companies to review the salary of the bus drivers?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, let me cite a list of the measures that are being taken by the bus company as a result of the recent spate of accidents.

    First of all, there will be another safety inspection of interchanges and terminals where all interchanges and terminals will undergo a comprehensive check to make sure that all the necessary safety features are in place and adequate. All new buses supplied since 1988 are fitted with speed limiters. In view of this spate of accidents, SBS will retrofit all the other buses with speed limiters. As I indicated earlier, a special exercise is now going on to check all schedules to ensure that there is adequate running and lay overtime. This is on top of the on-going periodic reviews of the schedules which are based on actual operations and which are done in consultation with the union.

    There will be a review of the drivers' salary scale. The terms and conditions of service for drivers will be reviewed to bring them more in line with the market rate. There will be a new accident-free incentive allowance to recognise and reward good and safe drivers. I think we must not forget that the majority of the drivers on the road are good drivers; they are safe drivers.

Column: 843



    Enforcement action against speeding and careless reversing has been stepped up. Traffic staff at interchanges have been reminding drivers on a daily basis to drive safely. An intensive campaign is under-way to enforce safe driving. Specifically, drivers are asked to drive at a safe speed, keep a safe distance from the front vehicle, whenever in doubt, apply brakes to slow down, to stop the bus, etc. Drivers' safety drills at junctions and pedestrian crossings have been introduced. Preparation is also being finalised for a safety dialogue between depot management and drivers in smaller groups.

    Finally, a series of activities to promote safety consciousness amongst bus passengers is also being planned.

    So I think the Member will appreciate that from this list of measures that are being taken, the authorities have asked the SBS to leave no stone unturned to make sure that the recent series of accidents that have caused public concern are minimised, if not eliminated.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, according to the list of steps the bus company has taken, it would appear that the most important one has been left out. The accidents are caused by human error. Surely they must study why there is such human error. I think that is the most important point, and they do not seem to include such studies whether or not the bus driver was under stress or worried about the family, or whatever factor that causes the human error. They should make a study of it.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, in so far as the specific accidents are concerned, the Traffic Police is the authority that is investigating the accidents. When the final report of the investigation is published, the Member will have another chance to ask any question that he may wish.

    But on that point alone, let me go further and tell this House what SBS drivers undergo as far as training is concerned. For new drivers, there is training for 12 days for class 4A licence. There is a 23-day familiarisation course

Column: 844

after this. There is a 33-day induction course after this. For refresher courses, drivers after three years of service are sent for a 3-day training course where their driving habits are picked up and where other corrective measures are taken. Then, in so far as the current training courses are concerned, these measures, including situation training, anti-stress training, training using simulators, are also being looked at and these will be done by a team of training experts from overseas. They will be invited to look into SBS' training programmes and see how improvements can be made.

Column: 844

PAYMENT OF HDB MONTHLY LOAN INSTALMENTS WITH CPF
(Topping up Ordinary Accounts with savings in Special Accounts)


    3. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Labour, in view of the increasing prices of Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats, whether he will allow HDB flat purchasers to top up their Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings in the Ordinary Accounts with their savings in the Special Accounts when the need arises, so that they can pay the HDB monthly loan instalments with their CPF.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Special Account forms part of every CPF member's account. Out of the total employer's and employee's contribution of 40%, 4 percentage points are credited to the Special Account. Savings in the Special Account cannot be used for servicing housing loan or investment purposes. This is to ensure that a CPF member will be able to accumulate some cash savings to meet his or her old age requirement. The cash savings in the Special Account will help many CPF members to satisfy the cash component of the revised Minimum Sum Scheme. Since the savings in the Special Account cannot be withdrawn for other purposes, Government has since 1st July 1995 paid a higher rate of interest on the Special Account savings. The premium is 1.25% more than the interest rate for the rest of the CPF savings.

Column: 845



    Sir, if the savings in the Special Account are routinely transferred for mortgage repayment, then we will not be able to achieve the objective of meeting CPF members' retirement needs. Nevertheless, we have under special circumstances allowed CPF members to use the Special Account savings for mortgage repayment. Members may recall that when the CPF rate was cut back by 15 percentage points in 1986 during the last economic downturn, CPF members were indeed allowed to use their Special Account savings to supplement mortgage repayments from their Ordinary Account savings. However, this practice was stopped in 1991 with the restoration of the CPF contribution rate to 40%.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, is the Minister aware that there are cases of flat purchasers who at the time of making a booking for a flat had enough money in the Ordinary Account to purchase the flat and also to pay for subsequent monthly loan instalments but, due to a delay or extended time, by the time they purchase the flat, it has already increased in price, and therefore the savings in the Ordinary Accounts are all exhausted to pay for the flat and the cash in hand is used to renovate the flat? Therefore, they have not enough savings in the Ordinary Account to pay for the monthly loan instalments. So they may need money from the Special Account to tide over, maybe for the first few instalments, so that they could save up enough to pay for subsequent monthly loan instalments.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, there may well be some home buyers who face the situation described by Mr Chiam. But as Mr Chiam himself pointed out, many of these people would have money for renovation but yet they say that they have inadequate CPF savings to meet the mortgage repayment. I would suggest that this is a matter of priority - which should come first? Purchase the home and then renovate it at some later stage when you have more money or to proceed immediately for renovation now and to

Column: 846

draw on the Special Account savings which are meant for very long term old-age retirement needs?

    I think we have to ask ourselves what was the original objective of the Special Account. It was to enable CPF members to put aside some cash savings, so that when they reach the age of 55, there will always be some cash savings which can go towards forming their retirement account under the Minimum Sum Scheme. If we allow this money to be withdrawn to meet mortgage repayment while the member spends his cash savings on renovation, then we are really eroding this effort to meet the retirement needs of the member, and I think in the long run it is not at all prudent to do so. We have debated extensively on the merits of the Minimum Sum Scheme. We should try our best to help members to accumulate sufficient cash savings so that they can meet all the requirements of the Minimum Sum Scheme.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Minister suggesting that a flat purchaser move into the flat without renovating the flat? In practice, I think you can hardly find one person who would move in without renovating the flat. In such circumstances, can the Minister not make a provision for payments to be paid out of the Special Account?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not suggesting that you move in without any renovation. I think it is a question of how extensive and how much money you want to spend on the renovation. If indeed you are short of a couple of payments on your mortgage loan, as the Member himself suggested earlier on, then maybe you could save on some of the other renovation items in order to make sure that you can meet these payments.

    Arising from this question, Mr Speaker, Sir, I asked my officers to check with HDB whether this is in fact a serious problem. The answer is that in 1995, the average sale price of a 4-room flat, for example, which was sold by HDB was around $125,000. These are flats in non-mature estate. We found that a person with a household income of about $1,753 could

Column: 847

buy such a flat with a mortgage loan of 80% repayable over 25 years. At this rate of repayment, the person is not consuming more than 25% of the household income, in which case the ordinary saving component of the husband and wife's income will be more than sufficient to meet the mortgage repayment. And therefore, it is not a problem to the vast majority of the home buyers in Singapore. In fact, 93% of all HDB home buyers, who are servicing their mortgage loan with CPF or cash, are able to do so from their CPF savings. In other words, 93% meet all their mortgage repayments completely from their CPF savings. There is very little need for them to top up with cash.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, what about flat purchasers, who have already budgeted what they already have in their Ordinary Accounts but could not meet the repayments because of increased prices in the flat? That is why they fall short.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, when a person applies to buy a flat, he has to take into account that there is a potential for some price increases. He cannot say that because he wants to buy a home at this price and when the price has gone up, we must change the whole rules of the game. It is quite clear that when he applies to buy a flat, he knows that he can only use the savings in his Ordinary Account. He should size the flat that he intends to buy on that basis, taking into account there is a potential for price increase or adjustment in the future. Investing in a home is a long-term investment. All of us are obliged to make careful calculation and consideration on the size or type of flat that we want to buy to make sure that we can afford it and we can service the mortgage repayments.

Column: 847

TRAFFIC JAM AT SINGAPORE END OF CAUSEWAY
(Reasons)


    4. Mr R. Sinnakaruppan asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for the traffic jam during peak periods at the Singapore immigration end

Column: 848

of the Singapore Johor Causeway and what will be done to have a smoother flow of traffic, especially during peak periods.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, one main reason for the congestion is a significant increase in the number of travellers passing through the Woodlands Checkpoint.

    In 1990, the daily average was about 176,000 travellers. This increased to 195,000 in 1994 and 203,000 in 1995. This is an increase of more than 15% over the last five years. There are also now more travellers who are not Malaysians and not Singaporeans using the Causeway. Compared to the previous year, the number of this group of travellers increased by 19%. Given the large number of travellers and those who drive through the Causeway every day, some traffic congestion is inevitable, especially during the peak hours.

    Singapore Immigration has taken measures to ease the congestion problem as much as possible and as far as it is feasible. For example, a new checking area with 12 lanes for clearance of motorcycles was introduced in May 1994. Since its implementation, the traffic situation at the Woodlands Checkpoint in the morning has improved significantly. The traffic flow is now smoother.

    To meet the ever increasing number of travellers using the Woodlands Checkpoint, the Immigration Department would also be embarking on a new pilot project called auto clearance by giving frequent travellers a smart card and let them travel through the Causeway almost hassle-free. But this is a pilot project which we will only launch next month to try out the system. And if this system works, then of course those who travel frequently to Malaysia will find it very convenient to travel through the Causeway.

    The congestion at the Checkpoint is essentially due to the Checkpoint's current inadequate capacity to deal with the crowd and the heavy flow during the peak periods from 5.00 to 8.00 in the evening when many vehicles want to depart for

Column: 849

Malaysia at the same time. Whatever measures we take can only bring about minimal improvement to the present situation. But the situation will improve substantially when a new Checkpoint is built in Woodlands and that will be in a couple of years' time and also when the second link at Tuas is completed. So with two places to cross between Singapore and Malaysia, I think the traffic flow will improve substantially in 1997 or 1998.

    Meanwhile, the Immigration Department, together with the Police, will continue to monitor the situation and take all the necessary measures to improve clearance speed. When there is a substantial jam or congestion during the peak periods, the Police will increase its manpower to try to clear the traffic.
